body: • The journalist and author Sally Brampton, who died this week, went to Ashford school, not Ashdown as we had it in a feature (‘She was never a follower’, 12 May, page 10, G2). The article also said Brampton’s daughter was 23 and an academic; she is now 24 and working in publishing. Finally, Nilgin Yusuf joined Elle in 1988, not 1998 as we had it. • Because of an editing error, a feature about the comedian Diane Morgan (Move over, Simon Schama, 11 May, page 18, G2) referred to “casting agents”, a conflation of the roles of agent and casting director. As our style guide states: “casting director … sometimes mistakenly referred to as a ‘casting agent’”. • Another editing error meant that the words in a pullquote on the letters page (12 May, page 34) were misattributed. As was clear in the body text, it was Paul Godier’s letter that said “If Tony Hall’s article is the best he can do to defend the BBC against the Tory onslaught, the beloved institution is doomed”, not Hugh Sheppard’s, which preceded Godier’s.
